docs.abstract: Interview with Jim Howley, who has become vigorous athlete since being diagnosed with AIDS seven years ago; he is set to compete in Hawaii's Ironman Triathlon and eight days later in New York City Marathon; benefits from combination of drugs that suppress AIDS virus and from intense exercise that prevents wasting away many AIDS patients suffer; photo (M)l

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical emergencies caused by very high blood pressure are often treated with a drug that is neither safe nor effective for the condition, a new study reports. In fact, use of the drug, the short-acting form of nifedipine, has become standard practice in many emergency rooms and offices, even though 11 years ago an advisory committee of the Food and Drug Administration unanimously recommended against this use of the drug.

headline.main: Drug Used in Emergencies Despite Warnings

docs.abstract: Medical emergencies caused by very high blood pressure are often being treated in hospital emergency rooms and offices with drug nifedipine, which is neither safe nor effective in that situation; FDA panel recommended against such use of short-acting form of drug eleven years ago; AMA Journal report by Franz H Messeril and three other doctors warns that patients have suffered strokes, heart attacks and other serious, sometimes fatal, complications; drug works so fast it can create cataclysmic danger, particularly in older people; Pfizer, which markets drug as Procardia, concurs; notes that company has never recommended using short-acting form for any form of high blood pressure (S)
